docs.lead_paragraph: Robert J. McDonald, who once held the second-highest post in Nassau County government, continued his testimony in federal court yesterday about how he became the pivotal inside man in a scheme that yielded $150,000 in bribes for himself and stuck the county with a health insurance plan that cost taxpayers tens of millions of dollars. ''There's money to be made in this for everybody,'' Mr. McDonald recalled being told by an intermediary, Herbert Schneider, now deceased. Mr. McDonald also quoted him as saying, ''You can make $50,000 out of this, and I can make $50,000 out of this.''

headline.main: Ex-Nassau Aide Tells of Role In County Insurance Scheme

docs.abstract: Robert J McDonald, who once held second-highest post in Nassau County, NY, continues testimony in fraud and bribery trial of Albert E Isernio, former president of Benefit Plan Administrators, company that handled insurance for Nassau County, NY, employees; tells how he became pivotal inside man in scheme that yielded $150,000 in bribes for himself and stuck county with health insurance plan that cost taxpayers tens of millions of dollars (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Bad Doctors Get a Free Ride,'' by Sidney M. Wolfe (Op-Ed, March 4): Just because a doctor has been sued or has paid a claim does not make him or her a bad or incompetent doctor. In fact, some of the best doctors in this country who take on the most complex, high-risk cases are those who get sued the most.
docs.abstract: American Medical Assn president Yank D Coble Jr letter contends lawsuits should not be marker of physician competence (Mar 7 Sidney M Wolfe Op-Ed)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''A Bad Prescription'' (editorial, March 5) may leave the misimpression that the elderly could be forced into private health plans if they want prescription drugs. Actually, the opposite is true under President Bush's framework for strengthening Medicare.
docs.abstract: Health and Human Services Sec Tommy G Thompson letter rejects Mar 5 editorial on prescription drugs for elderly; says Pres Bush's plan gives more choices and better benefits

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-8 U.S. Works to Gain 9 Votes for Iraq Measure After a weekend of diplomacy, the Bush administration fell short of lining up nine votes on the United Nations Security Council in favor of a resolution that would threaten war if Iraq does not disarm. A1 Iraq indicated that it would continue pursuing twin tracks in the face of a looming war -- taking steps to buttress the case of nations opposed to attacking the country while simultaneously preparing for battle. A9

docs.lead_paragraph: The clinic that bears this city's name was always a jewel of the American health care system, dispensing world-class care that cut no corners and made money, too. Its billion-dollar endowment rivaled that of giants like New York-Presbyterian Hospital and Memorial Sloan-Kettering in New York. But the clinic, the Cleveland Clinic Foundation, is struggling these days to live up to that privileged past. Nearly $500 million of its wealth -- almost a third of the assets it once had -- has vanished because of aggressive bets on a handful of technology stocks that fizzled.
docs.abstract: Cleveland Clinic has long been considered jewel of American health care system, dispensing world-class care that cut no corners and made money, too; now Cleveland Clinic Foundation has lost nearly $500 million of its wealth--almost third of assets it once had--because of aggressive bets on handful of technology stocks that fizzled; some doctors are being asked to work longer hours, routine investments on computer systems and on nursing stations are being postponed, and new chief financial officer is arrranging $750 million debt refinancing plan that he hopes will delay $140 million in loan payments for at least seven years; financial experts say Cleveland Clinic's situation is not unique; say many large hospital systems that used stock market returns to cover rising costs and skimpy insurance reimbursements have similar problems; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The clinic that bears this city's name was always a jewel of the American health care system, dispensing world-class care that cut no corners and made money, too. Its billion-dollar endowment rivaled that of giants like New York-Presbyterian Hospital...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Bush Medicare Proposal Urges Switch to Private Insurers'' (news article, March 5): The president's comments that introducing free-market competition to the Medicare system would give the elderly more choices and better treatment doesn't hold up to scrutiny.
docs.abstract: Ilene D Miner letter contends Pres Bush's Medicare proposal essentially forces elderly into private insurance programs with limited choices (Mar 5 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: Wear white lab coats at public appearances. Punish uncooperative colleagues. Above all, make sure patients experience colossal inconveniences. A month after thousands of New Jersey doctors staged a work stoppage to protest rising malpractice insurance rates, a series of e-mail messages between doctors and protest organizers making those and other recommendations offers an intriguing glimpse into the strategies and sentiments that drove the five-day job action.

headline.main: Anatomy of a Strike: Doctors' E-Mail Shows Depth of Anger

docs.abstract: One month after job action by doctors in New Jersey, e-mail messages between doctors and protest organizers reveal intense frustration and anger felt by physicians, many of whom blame trial lawyers, Democratic legislators and greedy patients for skyrocketing premiums; messages, distributed by consumer group Foundation for Taxpayer and Consumer Rights, which is opposed to doctors' demands, refer in disparaging terms to lawyers and to doctors who refuse to participate; some extreme protest strategies discussed; doctors in Connecticut and New York have scheduled similar job actions (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: President Bush's assertion that private health maintenance organizations, preferred provider organizations and other insurance plans can or will offer the elderly better benefits or more choices does not make economic sense (news article, March 5).
docs.abstract: Dr Mark Vonnegut letter contends that if it made sense for private insurers to be competing for business of elderly, they would already be doing so; says high costs, root of problem, must be addressed rather than simply shifted from one payer to another (Mar 5 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Study Raises Estimate of the Nation's Uninsured'' (news article, March 5): When I read the report that nearly a third of the American population younger than 65 were without health insurance at some time during the last two years, I contemplated the awful predicament of my recently unemployed patient, now uninsured and unable to obtain necessary tests and treatment for his heart disease.
